The title compound provides the first coordination network structure constructed together by bridging piperazine and btec mixed ligand.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A novel metal–organic compound Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btec)(pipz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) (btec=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, pipz=piperazine ) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectrum, TG analysis, luminescent spectrum and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The title compound exhibits a novel three-dimensional network, which consists of two-dimensional wave-like sheets linked by zinc metal centers and piperazine. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides the first coordination network structure constructed together by bridging piperazine and btec mixed ligand. The study of the physical properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> demonstrates that it exhibits a fluorescent emission in solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel metal-organic compound Zn2(btec)(pipz)(H2O) (1) (btec=1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, pipz=piperazine ) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectrum, TG analysis, luminescent spectrum and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The title compound exhibits a novel three-dimensional network, which consists of two-dimensional wave-like sheets linked by zinc metal centers and piperazine. Compound 1 provides the first coordination network structure constructed together by bridging piperazine and btec mixed ligand. The study of the physical properties of 1 demonstrates that it exhibits a fluorescent emission in solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The design and synthesis of metal–organic materials have attracted considerable interest in recent years arising from their fascinating molecular structures and potential applications as functional materials . Recently, bridging ligands have been extensively used because of their ability to serve as building blocks in the construction of metal–organic compounds . In particular, organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands, such as 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, as one class of multi-dentate bridging ligands, have been widely employed. As a result, several elegant examples of one-dimensional (1D) chain-like, two-dimensional (2D) layer-like and three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic compounds based on transition metal ions and polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared . Among these polycarboxylate ligands, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate is of great interest because of its enchanting and various structural features  and can be considered as a good candidate for the construction of multidimensional metal–organic compounds, especially 3D extended networks. Moreover, the introduction of a second aromatic organonitrogen ligand, such as didentate chelate ligands 2,2<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bipy or 1,10-phen , monodentate ligands imidazole  or <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-methylimidazole , or other co-ligands , to the M/btec (M=transitional metal) system has produced several interesting structures. However, metal–organic compounds constructured by btec and another bridging ligand have rarely been reported, especially the nonaromatic bridging ligand. The piperazine ligand, as a nonaromatic bridging ligand, usually acts as charge-compensating cation or structure-directing agent but rarely plays as bridging ligand . This is possible due to its distinct steric conformations. But under suitable reaction condition, it can also be a good bridging ligand to form extended framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of metal-organic materials have attracted considerable interest in recent years arising from their fascinating molecular structures and potential applications as functional materials . Recently, bridging ligands have been extensively used because of their ability to serve as building blocks in the construction of metal-organic compounds . In particular, organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands, such as 1,2-benzenedicarboxylate, 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, as one class of multi-dentate bridging ligands, have been widely employed. As a result, several elegant examples of one-dimensional (1D) chain-like, two-dimensional (2D) layer-like and three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic compounds based on transition metal ions and polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared . Among these polycarboxylate ligands, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate is of great interest because of its enchanting and various structural features  and can be considered as a good candidate for the construction of multidimensional metal-organic compounds, especially 3D extended networks. Moreover, the introduction of a second aromatic organonitrogen ligand, such as didentate chelate ligands 2,2'-bipy or 1,10-phen , monodentate ligands imidazole  or N-methylimidazole , or other co-ligands , to the M/btec (M=transitional metal) system has produced several interesting structures. However, metal-organic compounds constructured by btec and another bridging ligand have rarely been reported, especially the nonaromatic bridging ligand. The piperazine ligand, as a nonaromatic bridging ligand, usually acts as charge-compensating cation or structure-directing agent but rarely plays as bridging ligand . This is possible due to its distinct steric conformations. But under suitable reaction condition, it can also be a good bridging ligand to form extended framework.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Based on the above points, we have attempted to design and synthesize metal–organic compounds with btec and auxiliary nonaromatic bridging piperazine ligand. In this paper, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, X-ray crystal structure and fluorescent property of a novel 3D metal–organic compound Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btec)(pipz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). To our knowledge, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> represents the first metal–organic polymeric structure consisted of btec–pipz mixed-ligand in which piperazine and btec are both used as bridging ligands to connect two metal centers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Based on the above points, we have attempted to design and synthesize metal-organic compounds with btec and auxiliary nonaromatic bridging piperazine ligand. In this paper, we report the hydrothermal synthesis, X-ray crystal structure and fluorescent property of a novel 3D metal-organic compound Zn2(btec)(pipz)(H2O) (1). To our knowledge, compound 1 represents the first metal-organic polymeric structure consisted of btec-pipz mixed-ligand in which piperazine and btec are both used as bridging ligands to connect two metal centers.

Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. Zn was determined by a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. XPS analysis was performed on a VG ESCALABMK II spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−6</ce:sup> Pa during the analysis. IR spectrum was recorded in the range 400–4000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR Spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. Luminescence lifetimes were measured with a SPEX 1934D phosphorimeter using a 7 W pulse xenon lamp as the excitation source.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General procedures

All chemicals were commercially purchased and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer. Zn was determined by a PLASMA-SPEC(I) ICP atomic emission spectrometer. XPS analysis was performed on a VG ESCALABMK II spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2×10-6 Pa during the analysis. IR spectrum was recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR Spectrophotometer using KBr pellets. TG analysis was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °Cmin-1. Excitation and emission spectra were obtained on a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorometer equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Luminescence lifetimes were measured with a SPEX 1934D phosphorimeter using a 7 W pulse xenon lamp as the excitation source.

The synthesis of 1 

The title compound 1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. An aqueous mixture (8 ml) containing ZnCl2 (0.136 g), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (0.254 g), piperazine (0.086 g), and NaOH (0.16 g) was adjusted to pH 9.0 with 1 M NaOH aqueous under continuous stirring and then sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 ml), which was heated to 180 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling at 10 °C⋅h-1 to ambient temperature, yellow block-like crystals of compound 1 Zn2(btec)(pipz)(H2O) were mechanically separated from the white powder and washed by distilled water (Yield: ca. 70% based on Zn). Elemental analyses results of the yellow crystals are consistent with the stoichiometry of 1. Calc. for C14H14N2O9Zn2 (1): C, 34.6; H, 2.9; N, 5.8; Zn, 27.0. Found: C, 34.5; H, 2.8; N, 5.9; Zn, 26.8%. FT/IR data (cm-1): 3263(m), 3178(s), 3034(w), 2990(w), 2880(w), 1623(s), 1565(s), 1491(s), 1467(w), 1451(w), 1432(m), 1405(m), 1380(w), 1359(s), 1326(m), 1280(w), 1225(s), 1185(m), 1137(s), 1108(w), 1089(m), 1048(m), 1013(s), 942(m), 919(m), 888(s), 876(m), 867(w), 836(w), 821(m), 810(m), 765(s), 628(w), 585(m), 545(m), 486(w), 464(m), 420(m).

X-ray crystallography

The structure of compound 1 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. A yellow single crystal of 1 with dimensions 0.756×0.567×0.456 mm3 was mounted on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) at 293 K in the range of 2.21<θ<27.45°. Empirical absorption correction (ψ scan) was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 software . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. A total of 6561 (3442 unique, R int=0.0463) reflections were measured. Structure solution and refinement based on 3442 independent reflections with I>2σ(I) and 244 parameters gave R 1(wR 2)=0.0297 (0.0853) {R 1=∑||F o|-|F c||/∑|F  rmo |; wR 2=∑[w(F o 2-F c 2)2]/∑[w(F o 2)2]1/2}.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">CCDC reference number: 212599</ce:para><ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is constructed via a self-assembly process under hydrothermal conditions. Recently, hydrothermal synthesis has been proved to be a powerful method for the construction of metal–organic coordination polymer containing mixed organic ligands. In such a relatively low temperature and autogenous pressure environment, problems of different solubility for various ligands are minimized, and appropriate O-donor and N-donor ligands may be selected by the metal centers for efficient molecular building during the crystallization process . The pH value is very important to the generation of the high-dimensional structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the carboxyl groups of btec ligands are all deprotonated, and the pipz ligand cannot be protonated in such basic condition. To our knowledge, the coordination polymers where pipz ligand functions as counter cations are prepared in acidic or neutral conditions, such as [{M(btec)(OH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>{C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (M=Co; Ni; Zn; C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=piperazine) , (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>hpz)[Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(btec)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>11H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  and (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>hpz)[Co(btec)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>hpz=homopiperazonium). Thus, the high pH value may increase the coordination capability of pipz ligand, and at the same time, prevent the tendency to be protonated, which offers the opportunity for piperazine to connect two metal centers as a bridging ligand. It is worthy to mention that when other metal ions, such as Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, and Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> were used, no similar result was obtained in such a reaction system. This proved that the coordination geometry of zinc atoms is significant to form such a structure.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
CCDC reference number: 212599

Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

The compound 1 is constructed via a self-assembly process under hydrothermal conditions. Recently, hydrothermal synthesis has been proved to be a powerful method for the construction of metal-organic coordination polymer containing mixed organic ligands. In such a relatively low temperature and autogenous pressure environment, problems of different solubility for various ligands are minimized, and appropriate O-donor and N-donor ligands may be selected by the metal centers for efficient molecular building during the crystallization process . The pH value is very important to the generation of the high-dimensional structure of 1, the carboxyl groups of btec ligands are all deprotonated, and the pipz ligand cannot be protonated in such basic condition. To our knowledge, the coordination polymers where pipz ligand functions as counter cations are prepared in acidic or neutral conditions, such as [{M(btec)(OH2)4}⋅{C4H12N2}⋅4H2O]n (M=Co; Ni; Zn; C4H10N2=piperazine) , (H4hpz)[Co3(btec)2(H2O)12]⋅11H2O  and (H4hpz)[Co(btec)(H2O)3]⋅3H2O  (H4hpz=homopiperazonium). Thus, the high pH value may increase the coordination capability of pipz ligand, and at the same time, prevent the tendency to be protonated, which offers the opportunity for piperazine to connect two metal centers as a bridging ligand. It is worthy to mention that when other metal ions, such as CuII, CoII, and NiII were used, no similar result was obtained in such a reaction system. This proved that the coordination geometry of zinc atoms is significant to form such a structure.

<ce:para view="all">The TG curve of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="MMC2"></ce:float-anchor>) exhibits two steps of weight losses. The first weight loss is 3.98% (calc. 3.71%) in the range of 340–380 °C, corresponding to the release of coordination water. The second weight loss is 61.72% (calc. 62.89%) in the temperature range of 390–480 °C, corresponding to the release of piperazine and btec ligands. The sample does not lose weight at temperatures higher than 480 °C. The residue is ZnO.</ce:para>

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>The crystal structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a three-dimensional (3D) polymer with two kinds of ligands bridging between the zinc ions. All carboxyl groups of btec ligands in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are deprotonated and two types of btec ligands are present in the structure. (a) Eight oxygen atoms from four deprotonated carboxyl groups of btec ligand are all used as coordinating atoms. Four oxygen atoms from two neighboring carboxyl groups coordinate to three zinc atoms. Among which, two oxygen atom adopt 1,6-bidentate chelating mode connecting to one Zn atom and the other two link with two Zn atoms with monodentate mode; the remaining four oxygen atoms of the btec ligand coordinate to other three zinc atoms with the same mode (<ce:sup loc="pre">a</ce:sup>btec, ) . (b) Each carboxyl group adopts monodentate coordination mode linking to four Zn atoms (<ce:sup loc="pre">b</ce:sup>btec, ). There are two crystallographically unique Zn centers in the crystal structure, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>. The Zn(1) center shows a distorted square pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand and four oxygen atoms, two from two <ce:sup loc="pre">b</ce:sup>btec ligand, and other two from one <ce:sup loc="pre">a</ce:sup>btec ligand. The Zn(2) center adopts distorted tetrahedral geometry coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand, two oxygen atoms from two <ce:sup loc="pre">a</ce:sup>btec ligand and one oxygen donors from one water molecule. The average Zn–N bond length is 2.0484(2) Å. The Zn–O bond lengths vary from 1.963(2) to 2.2568 Å, while Zn–OW bond length is 1.988(2) Å. If we neglect piperazine ligand and Zn(2) ions, a 2-D sheet structure is observed (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>). The sheet is made up of a rhombic grid with four <ce:sup loc="pre">a</ce:sup>btec ligands on the corners, four Zn(1) atoms on the edges and one <ce:sup loc="pre">b</ce:sup>btec ligand that bridges between two of the Zn(1) atoms in the center of the rhombic grid. The size of these rhombic grids is ca. 8.9<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>12.9 Å. It is very interesting that the 2-D sheet is a wave-like structure viewed from the side (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>), and such wave-like sheets composed of two types of btec ligand has not been observed so far. The distance between two neighboring crests is ca. 11.5 Å. All Zn(1) atoms are in the position of crest and trough. Further, Zn(2) atoms, functioning as linkers, link two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two <ce:sup loc="pre">a</ce:sup>btec ligand belonging to adjacent sheets to produce the 3D framework (see ). It is very interesting that the other bridging ligands piperazine are in the interlayer region linking to Zn(1) atoms and Zn(2) atoms () with chair conformation. Therefore, the 3D structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is produced by the combination of btec ligand and piperazine ligand, to our knowledge, such combination has not been reported.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The crystal structure of compound 1 

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) polymer with two kinds of ligands bridging between the zinc ions. All carboxyl groups of btec ligands in compound 1 are deprotonated and two types of btec ligands are present in the structure. (a) Eight oxygen atoms from four deprotonated carboxyl groups of btec ligand are all used as coordinating atoms. Four oxygen atoms from two neighboring carboxyl groups coordinate to three zinc atoms. Among which, two oxygen atom adopt 1,6-bidentate chelating mode connecting to one Zn atom and the other two link with two Zn atoms with monodentate mode; the remaining four oxygen atoms of the btec ligand coordinate to other three zinc atoms with the same mode (abtec, ) . (b) Each carboxyl group adopts monodentate coordination mode linking to four Zn atoms (bbtec, ). There are two crystallographically unique Zn centers in the crystal structure, as shown in  . The Zn(1) center shows a distorted square pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand and four oxygen atoms, two from two bbtec ligand, and other two from one abtec ligand. The Zn(2) center adopts distorted tetrahedral geometry coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand, two oxygen atoms from two abtec ligand and one oxygen donors from one water molecule. The average Zn-N bond length is 2.0484(2) Å. The Zn-O bond lengths vary from 1.963(2) to 2.2568 Å, while Zn-OW bond length is 1.988(2) Å. If we neglect piperazine ligand and Zn(2) ions, a 2-D sheet structure is observed (see  ). The sheet is made up of a rhombic grid with four abtec ligands on the corners, four Zn(1) atoms on the edges and one bbtec ligand that bridges between two of the Zn(1) atoms in the center of the rhombic grid. The size of these rhombic grids is ca. 8.9×12.9 Å. It is very interesting that the 2-D sheet is a wave-like structure viewed from the side (see  ), and such wave-like sheets composed of two types of btec ligand has not been observed so far. The distance between two neighboring crests is ca. 11.5 Å. All Zn(1) atoms are in the position of crest and trough. Further, Zn(2) atoms, functioning as linkers, link two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two abtec ligand belonging to adjacent sheets to produce the 3D framework (see ). It is very interesting that the other bridging ligands piperazine are in the interlayer region linking to Zn(1) atoms and Zn(2) atoms () with chair conformation. Therefore, the 3D structure of compound 1 is produced by the combination of btec ligand and piperazine ligand, to our knowledge, such combination has not been reported.

elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent property

The luminescent spectra of 1 and the free H4btec ligand in the solid state at room temperature are shown in   and  . The emissions of 1 [λ max=489.00 nm, (τ=0.016 ms)] (τ=lifetime; the short lifetime suggests that luminescence should be assigned to fluorescence) can be observed upon photoexcitation at 442.00 nm, while emission of the free H4btec (λ max=342.00 nm) is upon photoexcitation at 308.00 nm. Thus, the blue fluorescence may be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . A similar emission band has also been observed in other zinc-organic polymer compounds . Compound 1 may be used as an advanced material for blue-light emitting diode devices because of the blue fluorescence emission. This condensed polymeric material may be an excellent candidate for highly thermally stable and solvent-resistant blue fluorescent material because 1 is highly thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and non-polar solvents such as ethanol, chloroform, acetone, and water .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this work, we report a novel metal–organic complex Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btec)(pipz)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), which is prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis route. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a novel three-dimensional network constructed from bridging btec and piperazine mixed ligand. The successful isolation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> not only confirms that such metal–organic compounds may be designed and synthesized according to the inherent stereo and interactive information stored in the organic ligands and metal ions , but also further proves the strong capability of hydrothermal reactions in preparing novel metal–organic materials with mixed organic ligands. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits strong blue fluorescent emission and may be an excellent candidate for potential photoactive material.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we report a novel metal-organic complex Zn2(btec)(pipz)(H2O) (1), which is prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis route. Compound 1 exhibits a novel three-dimensional network constructed from bridging btec and piperazine mixed ligand. The successful isolation of compound 1 not only confirms that such metal-organic compounds may be designed and synthesized according to the inherent stereo and interactive information stored in the organic ligands and metal ions , but also further proves the strong capability of hydrothermal reactions in preparing novel metal-organic materials with mixed organic ligands. Compound 1 exhibits strong blue fluorescent emission and may be an excellent candidate for potential photoactive material.

cln_elements.clean_text:
The synthesis of 1 

The title compound 1 was hydrothermally synthesized under autogenous pressure. An aqueous mixture (8 ml) containing ZnCl2 (0.136 g), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (0.254 g), piperazine (0.086 g), and NaOH (0.16 g) was adjusted to pH 9.0 with 1 M NaOH aqueous under continuous stirring and then sealed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 ml), which was heated to 180 °C for 72 h. After slowly cooling at 10 °C⋅h-1 to ambient temperature, yellow block-like crystals of compound 1 Zn2(btec)(pipz)(H2O) were mechanically separated from the white powder and washed by distilled water (Yield: ca. 70% based on Zn). Elemental analyses results of the yellow crystals are consistent with the stoichiometry of 1. Calc. for C14H14N2O9Zn2 (1): C, 34.6; H, 2.9; N, 5.8; Zn, 27.0. Found: C, 34.5; H, 2.8; N, 5.9; Zn, 26.8%. FT/IR data (cm-1): 3263(m), 3178(s), 3034(w), 2990(w), 2880(w), 1623(s), 1565(s), 1491(s), 1467(w), 1451(w), 1432(m), 1405(m), 1380(w), 1359(s), 1326(m), 1280(w), 1225(s), 1185(m), 1137(s), 1108(w), 1089(m), 1048(m), 1013(s), 942(m), 919(m), 888(s), 876(m), 867(w), 836(w), 821(m), 810(m), 765(s), 628(w), 585(m), 545(m), 486(w), 464(m), 420(m).

cln_elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

The structure of compound 1 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. A yellow single crystal of 1 with dimensions 0.756×0.567×0.456 mm3 was mounted on a glass fiber. Data were collected on a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID IP diffractometer with Mo Kα (λ=0.71073 Å) at 293 K in the range of 2.21<θ<27.45°. Empirical absorption correction (ψ scan) was applied. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the SHELXS-97 software . All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located from difference Fourier maps. A total of 6561 (3442 unique, R int=0.0463) reflections were measured. Structure solution and refinement based on 3442 independent reflections with I>2σ(I) and 244 parameters gave R 1(wR 2)=0.0297 (0.0853) {R 1=∑||F o|-|F c||/∑|F  rmo |; wR 2=∑[w(F o 2-F c 2)2]/∑[w(F o 2)2]1/2}.

The TG curve of compound 1 ( ) exhibits two steps of weight losses. The first weight loss is 3.98% (calc. 3.71%) in the range of 340-380 °C, corresponding to the release of coordination water. The second weight loss is 61.72% (calc. 62.89%) in the temperature range of 390-480 °C, corresponding to the release of piperazine and btec ligands. The sample does not lose weight at temperatures higher than 480 °C. The residue is ZnO.

The crystal structure of compound 1 

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that compound 1 is a three-dimensional (3D) polymer with two kinds of ligands bridging between the zinc ions. All carboxyl groups of btec ligands in compound 1 are deprotonated and two types of btec ligands are present in the structure. (a) Eight oxygen atoms from four deprotonated carboxyl groups of btec ligand are all used as coordinating atoms. Four oxygen atoms from two neighboring carboxyl groups coordinate to three zinc atoms. Among which, two oxygen atom adopt 1,6-bidentate chelating mode connecting to one Zn atom and the other two link with two Zn atoms with monodentate mode; the remaining four oxygen atoms of the btec ligand coordinate to other three zinc atoms with the same mode (abtec, ) . (b) Each carboxyl group adopts monodentate coordination mode linking to four Zn atoms (bbtec, ). There are two crystallographically unique Zn centers in the crystal structure, as shown in  . The Zn(1) center shows a distorted square pyramidal geometry and is coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand and four oxygen atoms, two from two bbtec ligand, and other two from one abtec ligand. The Zn(2) center adopts distorted tetrahedral geometry coordinated by one nitrogen atom of a piperazine ligand, two oxygen atoms from two abtec ligand and one oxygen donors from one water molecule. The average Zn-N bond length is 2.0484(2) Å. The Zn-O bond lengths vary from 1.963(2) to 2.2568 Å, while Zn-OW bond length is 1.988(2) Å. If we neglect piperazine ligand and Zn(2) ions, a 2-D sheet structure is observed (see  ). The sheet is made up of a rhombic grid with four abtec ligands on the corners, four Zn(1) atoms on the edges and one bbtec ligand that bridges between two of the Zn(1) atoms in the center of the rhombic grid. The size of these rhombic grids is ca. 8.9×12.9 Å. It is very interesting that the 2-D sheet is a wave-like structure viewed from the side (see  ), and such wave-like sheets composed of two types of btec ligand has not been observed so far. The distance between two neighboring crests is ca. 11.5 Å. All Zn(1) atoms are in the position of crest and trough. Further, Zn(2) atoms, functioning as linkers, link two oxygen atoms from two carboxyl groups of two abtec ligand belonging to adjacent sheets to produce the 3D framework (see ). It is very interesting that the other bridging ligands piperazine are in the interlayer region linking to Zn(1) atoms and Zn(2) atoms () with chair conformation. Therefore, the 3D structure of compound 1 is produced by the combination of btec ligand and piperazine ligand, to our knowledge, such combination has not been reported.

Fluorescent property

The luminescent spectra of 1 and the free H4btec ligand in the solid state at room temperature are shown in   and  . The emissions of 1 [λ max=489.00 nm, (τ=0.016 ms)] (τ=lifetime; the short lifetime suggests that luminescence should be assigned to fluorescence) can be observed upon photoexcitation at 442.00 nm, while emission of the free H4btec (λ max=342.00 nm) is upon photoexcitation at 308.00 nm. Thus, the blue fluorescence may be assigned as ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . A similar emission band has also been observed in other zinc-organic polymer compounds . Compound 1 may be used as an advanced material for blue-light emitting diode devices because of the blue fluorescence emission. This condensed polymeric material may be an excellent candidate for highly thermally stable and solvent-resistant blue fluorescent material because 1 is highly thermally stable and insoluble in common polar and non-polar solvents such as ethanol, chloroform, acetone, and water .
